<h2>#04 - Sorting strings with accented characters</h2> <blockquote><p>2016-01-04 by <a href="https://twitter.com/loverajoel">@loverajoel</a></p></blockquote> <p>Javascript has a native method <strong><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/sort">sort</a></strong> that allows sorting arrays. Doing a simple <code>array.sort()</code> will treat each array entry as a string and sort it alphabetically. Also you can provide your <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/sort#Parameters">own custom sorting</a> function.</p> <p><code>javascript [&#39;Shanghai&#39;, &#39;New York&#39;, &#39;Mumbai&#39;, &#39;Buenos Aires&#39;].sort(); // [&quot;Buenos Aires&quot;, &quot;Mumbai&quot;, &quot;New York&quot;, &quot;Shanghai&quot;] </code></p> <p>But when you try order an array of non ASCII characters like this <code>[&#39;é&#39;, &#39;a&#39;, &#39;ú&#39;, &#39;c&#39;]</code>, you will obtain a strange result <code>[&#39;c&#39;, &#39;e&#39;, &#39;á&#39;, &#39;ú&#39;]</code>. That happens because sort works only with english language.</p> <p>See the next example:</p> <p><code></code>`javascript // Spanish [&#39;único&#39;,&#39;árbol&#39;, &#39;cosas&#39;, &#39;fútbol&#39;].sort(); // [&quot;cosas&quot;, &quot;fútbol&quot;, &quot;árbol&quot;, &quot;único&quot;] // bad order</p> <p>// German [&#39;Woche&#39;, &#39;wöchentlich&#39;, &#39;wäre&#39;, &#39;Wann&#39;].sort(); // [&quot;Wann&quot;, &quot;Woche&quot;, &quot;wäre&quot;, &quot;wöchentlich&quot;] // bad order <code></code>`</p> <p>Fortunately, there are two ways to overcome this behavior <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/localeCompare">localeCompare</a> and <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Collator">Intl.Collator</a> provided by ECMAScript Internationalization API.</p> <blockquote><p>Both methods have their own custom parameters in order to configure it to work adequately.</p></blockquote> <h3>Using <code>localeCompare()</code></h3> <p><code></code>`javascript [&#39;único&#39;,&#39;árbol&#39;, &#39;cosas&#39;, &#39;fútbol&#39;].sort(function (a, b) { return a.localeCompare(b); }); // [&quot;árbol&quot;, &quot;cosas&quot;, &quot;fútbol&quot;, &quot;único&quot;]</p> <p>[&#39;Woche&#39;, &#39;wöchentlich&#39;, &#39;wäre&#39;, &#39;Wann&#39;].sort(function (a, b) { return a.localeCompare(b); }); // [&quot;Wann&quot;, &quot;wäre&quot;, &quot;Woche&quot;, &quot;wöchentlich&quot;] <code></code>`</p> <h3>Using <code>Intl.Collator()</code></h3> <p><code></code>`javascript [&#39;único&#39;,&#39;árbol&#39;, &#39;cosas&#39;, &#39;fútbol&#39;].sort(Intl.Collator().compare); // [&quot;árbol&quot;, &quot;cosas&quot;, &quot;fútbol&quot;, &quot;único&quot;]</p> <p>[&#39;Woche&#39;, &#39;wöchentlich&#39;, &#39;wäre&#39;, &#39;Wann&#39;].sort(Intl.Collator().compare); // [&quot;Wann&quot;, &quot;wäre&quot;, &quot;Woche&quot;, &quot;wöchentlich&quot;] <code></code>`</p> <ul><li>For each method you can customize the location.</li><li>According to <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/localeCompare#Performance">Firefox</a> Intl.Collator is faster when comparing large numbers of strings.</li></ul> <p>So when you are working with arrays of strings in a language other than English, remember to use this method to avoid unexpected sorting.</p>
